k)   Employee Participation - We have a written employee participation program for covered processes to help ensure that the safety concerns of our workers are addressed. We encourage active participation of personnel in the prevention program activities of all processes at the facility. Employees are consulted on and informed about all aspects of our accidental release prevention program.

l)   Hot Work Permits - We have a hot work permit program to control spark- or flame-producing activities that could result in fires or explosions in our facility. We reviewed OSHA's fire prevention and protection requirements and created a hot work permit system to comply with these requirements. Training in the use of the hot work permit system is included in our safe work practices orientation.

m)   Contractors - We have a program in place to help ensure that contractor activities at our facility are performed in a safe manner. This program reviews the safety record of all our contractors to help ensure that we hire only contractors who can safely perform the desired tasks. We explain to the contract supervisors the hazards of the process on which they and their employees will work, our safe work practices, and our emergency action procedures. The Contractor is required to ensure that training has been performed for each of their employees who work at the facility before that worker begins work at our facility. And finally, we periodically review contractors' training documents and work performance to help ensure that safe practices are followed.

5.   Five-Year Accident History (§68.155(d)):
There have been no reportable incidents during the past five years.

7.   Emergency Response Notification Activities
We coordinate response needs at least annually with local emergency planning and response organizations, providing the following:

a)   Our emergency action plan,
b)   Any updated emergency contact information, and
c)   any other information identified by local responders as relevant to local emergency response planning.

8.   Emergency Response Notification Exercises
We conduct an annual exercise of our emergency response notification mechanisms.

We constantly strive to improve the safety of our processes using recommendations developed through the prevention program and a program soliciting safety suggestions from our employees. Based on the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for anhydrous ammonia, a list of action items was developed. Therefore, we perform safety reviews of new or modified processes before placing them into service to help ensure their safe operation. This review confirms that: (1) construction and equipment are in accordance with design specifications, (2) adequate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place, (3) employee training has been completed, and (4) a PHA has been performed (if required) if the process is new or management of change requirements have been completed if an existing process has been modified.

h)   Compliance Audit - One of the cornerstones of an effective prevention program is a regular, thorough assessment. We audit our covered process every 3 years to be certain our program is effectively addressing the safety issues of our operations. We assemble an audit team that includes personnel knowledgeable in the PSM and RMP rules and in our process design, and this team evaluates whether the prevention program satisfies the requirements of these rules and whether it is sufficient to help ensure safe operation of the process. The results of the audit are documented, recommendations are resolved, and appropriate enhancements to the prevention program are implemented.

i)   Third-Party Audit - Should we experience an accidental release that results in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage, we will employ an independent, third-party to conduct the next Compliance Audit.

j)   Incident Investigation - We investigate all incidents that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in (i.e., a near miss) serious injury to personnel, the public, or the environment so that similar accidents can be prevented in the future. d)   Training - We train workers to safely and effectively perform their assigned tasks. Our training program includes both initial and refresher training that covers (1) a general overview of the process, (2) the properties and hazards associated with anhydrous ammonia, and (3) a detailed review of the process operating procedures and safe work practices. On-the-Job Training and Evaluation is used to verify that an employee understands the training material before the employee can begin or resume work on the system.

e)   Mechanical Integrity - We maintain our process equipment to help prevent equipment failures that could endanger workers, the public, or the environment. Our mechanical integrity (preventive maintenance) program includes (1) inspection and testing program to help identify equipment deficiencies and damage before the equipment fails and (2) a quality assurance program to help ensure that new and replacement equipment meet the strict design standards required for service in our process.

f)   Management of Change - We evaluate and specifically approve all proposed changes to chemicals, equipment, technology, and procedures to help ensure that the change does not negatively affect safe operations. All changes other than replacement-in-kind must be approved through the full management of change program. This helps ensure that inadvertent consequences of process changes are prevented, safety consequences of changes are addressed, affected process safety information and procedures are updated, and affected employees are notified of the changes.

a)   Process Safety Information - We maintain a variety of technical documents, including an emergency preparedness plan, to help ensure that employees and local emergency responders know about the hazards associated with our facility. These documents address (1) physical properties of anhydrous ammonia, (2) operating parameters for our equipment, and (3) design basis and configuration for our equipment. We ensure that this process safety information is available to all our employees.

b)   Process Hazard Analysis - We perform and periodically update process hazard analysis (PHAs) for our covered process to help identify process hazards and make recommendations that might improve the safe operation of the process. A multidisciplinary team is assembled to analyze the hazards of our process. This team includes personnel with engineering and process operating experience and a leader with PHA experience. The team systematically addresses the hazards associated with operation of the equipment in the covered process. The team then prepares a written report describing the results of the analysis, including a list of recommendations.

Responsibility for resolving the recommendations is assigned to plant personnel, and, when appropriate, changes to enhance the safety of the process are implemented. The analysis is revisited at least every 5 years to ensure it is current.

c)   Operating Procedures - Our operators and managers work together to develop and maintain operating procedures to define how tasks related to process operations should be safety performed. Emergency Action - We have developed an OSHA hazardous substance Emergency Action Plan. This plan outlines specific procedures for evacuations, incident alarms and alerting.  Depending upon a given situation, the Lodi Fire Department will be called to provide emergency responders and equipment. The Lodi Fire Department will be called for all fire related emergencies. The facility has communicated the hazard of anhydrous ammonia with the Lodi Fire Department and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). The incident commander has ultimate control of the implementation of the emergency response.

Our internal emergency communications program ensures that all supervisors and employees in areas affected by an inadvertent chemical leak are warned and evacuated, if necessary, and immediate steps are taken to evaluate and stop the leak. To ensure that we are adequately addressed in the community emergency response plan and to ensure that local response organizations are aware of our facility, annual coordination exercises are conducted. Additionally, we conduct an annual exercise of our notification mechanisms.

FACILITY DESCRIPTION
Rich Products Lodi is located at 40 Neuharth Drive in Lodi, CA.

The facility consists of a processing plant used to manufacture and bakery products, which are frozen for shipment. The Site's North American Industrial Classification System (NAICS) code is 311812 (Commercial Bakeries). As part of the Site's refrigeration system, which is used to freeze the bakery products for shipment, the Site handles quantities of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance/highly hazardous chemical as defined in the USEPA's RMP Rule, Cal OES CalARP program, and OSHA's PSM standard, in an amount exceeding the regulatory threshold for anhydrous ammonia in a single process, i.e., the Site's refrigeration system. The Facility is registered to Program Level 3 under the USEPA CAPP and Cal OES CalARP programs. The Facility normally operates 6 days per week, 24 hours per day and maintains approximately 340 full time employees.

The anhydrous ammonia, which is liquefied under pressure, is contained in various vessels, accumulators, piping, and heat exchangers throughout the refrigeration system. The majority of the Site’s refrigeration machinery is located outside, adjacent to the building.

1.   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Action (§68.155(a) and §2745.3(a)): Protecting the health and safety of our employees and neighbors, and of the surrounding environment, is our top priority, and we have a comprehensive program in place to reduce risks associated with our process.

Hazard Assessment and Reduction - We regularly assess the risks associated with the use of anhydrous ammonia in our manufacturing processes and seek out ways in which to reduce those risks.

Accident Prevention - We engineer and construct our manufacturing processes and equipment to minimize the possibility of accidental chemical releases.
